title: How to Make Biscuits from Scratch

steps.headline: Dissolve the yeast in water.
steps.description: Combine the warm water and yeast in a large bowl, stirring gently only to dissolve the yeast. The water should be between 110 and 115 degrees Fahrenheit (43 and 46 degrees Celsius) in order to activate the yeast properly. Use a food thermometer to check the temperature of the water before you add the yeast.

steps.headline: Add the sugar, butter, milk, egg, salt, and whole wheat flour.
steps.description: Combine these ingredients with the yeast-water mixture and beat with a mixing spoon until smooth. You could use an electric mixer set to low speed instead of a mixing spoon, if desired. Make sure to beat the egg slightly with a fork to combine the yolk and white before adding it to the mixture. Use softened butter. To soften butter, let it sit out at room temperature for 30 to 60 minutes. You could also soften butter by microwaving it for 15 seconds at 30 percent power.

steps.headline: Add the all-purpose flour.
steps.description: Gradually add the all-purpose flour to the mix, stopping once a soft dough forms. If you have a stand mixer with a dough attachment, you can use it to fold the flour into the dough. If not, you will need to use a mixing spoon or your hands. Do not use an electric hand mixer.

steps.headline: Knead the dough.
steps.description: Turn the dough out onto a clean, lightly floured surface and knead until it becomes smooth an elastic. This usually takes about 10 minutes. If the dough sticks to your hands as you knead it, you can apply a light dusting of flour to your hands to help prevent further sticking.

steps.headline: Let rise in a warm place.
steps.description: Place the dough in a greased bowl and let it rise, covered, until it doubles in volume. The dough will usually need to rise for about 1 hour and 30 minutes. You can grease the bowl with nonstick cooking spray, butter, or shortening. Turn the dough after putting it into the greased bowl once in order to grease the top. Make sure that the dough is placed in a warm area. Otherwise, it may not reach its full rising potential. Cover the bowl with a lid or warm, moist towel.

steps.headline: Punch down the dough and divide it into thirds.
steps.description: After the dough rises, punch it down and separate it into three equal pieces. Allow those three pieces to rest for 5 minutes, regaining some volume in the process. This might be a good time to preheat your oven. Preheat the oven to 375 degrees Fahrenheit (190 degrees Celsius), and prepare a baking sheet by spraying it with nonstick cooking spray or greasing it with butter or shortening.

steps.headline: Flatten the dough.
steps.description: Use a rolling pin to flatten each third on a floured counter top. Each piece of dough should be about 1/2 inch (1.25 cm) thick. Rub a little flour onto the rolling pin to prevent it from sticking to the dough.

steps.headline: Cut out biscuits.
steps.description: Use a 2.5-inch (6.35-cm) round biscuit cutter to cut out as many biscuits as possible. Transfer these round pieces of dough to your prepared baking sheet and let rise for another 30 minutes, or until doubled in volume. If you do not have a biscuit cutter, you could also use a cookie cutter or the open rim of a glass. Choose a glass with a fairly sharp, well-defined rim in order to create even circles.

steps.headline: Cook the biscuits for 10 to 12 minutes.
steps.description: Place the biscuits in your oven, preheated to 375 degrees Fahrenheit (190 degrees Celsius). Back the biscuits until they become golden brown.

steps.headline: Serve warm.
steps.description: Remove the pans from the oven and let them cool for several minutes on wire racks. Serve the biscuits once they are cool enough to touch. Always use oven mitts or a thick kitchen towel when handling a hot baking sheet.

methods.name:
Baking Powder Biscuits[3]
	X
		Research source

steps.headline: Preheat the oven to 425 degrees Fahrenheit (218 degrees Celsius).
steps.description: Prepare a shallow baking sheet by lining it with parchment paper. Alternatively, you could lightly grease the pan with butter, shortening, or nonstick baking spray instead of using parchment paper. If you have a nonstick baking mat, you could use that instead of a prepared baking sheet.

steps.headline: Combine the flour, baking powder, and salt.
steps.description: Stir the three ingredients together in a medium to large mixing bowl until thoroughly combined. If desired, you could replace half of the all-purpose flour with whole wheat flour.

steps.headline: Cut and put in the butter.
steps.description: Slice the butter into 1/2-inch (1.25-cm) cubes before tossing them into the flour mixture. Blend them into the flour using a pastry blender until large, coarse crumbs form. The crumbs should be about the size of a pea. If you do not have a pastry blender, you could cut the butter into the flour mixture by using two knives to stir and chop the butter while immersed in the flour mixture.

steps.headline: Add the milk.
steps.description: Pour the milk in, stirring it into the dry ingredients until moistened. Use a fork or spatula to stir. Stop as soon as the dry ingredients are moistened. Over-mixing the dough could create tough, chewy biscuits.

steps.headline: Knead the dough.
steps.description: Turn the dough onto a clean, lightly floured surface and knead several times until the dough sticks together. Gently pat the dough into a rounded or rectangular shape. At this point, the dough should be about 3/4 inch (2 cm) thick. Fold the dough into three sections in order to create biscuits that have multiple, flaky layers. Overlap the ends over the center of the dough, creating a brochure-style fold. After folding the dough, flatten as usual to the specified thickness.

steps.headline: Cut out biscuits.
steps.description: Use a round, 3-inch (7.5-cm) biscuit cutter with sharp edges to cut out rounds of dough. Place the biscuits onto your prepared baking sheet, spacing them about 1 inch (2.5 cm) apart. A cookie cutter or the mouth of a glass could be used in the absence of an actual biscuit cutter. After your first batch of biscuits has been cut out, pat the scraps together again so that you can cut out more biscuits from the remaining dough. Continue until all the dough has been used. While circular biscuits are the most traditional shape, you could cut your biscuits into any shape desired. Cutting the biscuits into squares will prevent you from having to roll out any excess dough. Alternatively, create drop biscuits by dropping rounded tablespoons of dough onto your baking sheet. This will create biscuits that are more rustic in appearance.

steps.headline: Bake the biscuits for 15 to 18 minutes.
steps.description: The biscuits should be a light, golden brown when done. Note that if you opted to form drop biscuits instead of cut biscuits, the peaks of dough will be slightly darker and crispy when the biscuits are done.

steps.headline: Serve warm.
steps.description: The biscuits can be served immediately, or you can let them cool slightly on a wire rack for a few minutes first. Use oven mitts or a thick dish towel when removing the biscuits from the oven.

steps.headline: Make biscuits using self-rising flour.
steps.description: Biscuits prepared with self-rising flour may rise better than those made with standard all-purpose flour.

steps.headline: Substitute sour cream for the milk.
steps.description: Sour cream biscuits are generally a bit denser, richer, and flatter than those prepared with milk.

steps.headline: Use buttermilk.
steps.description: Tangy buttermilk is a common ingredient found in Southern-style biscuits, and using buttermilk instead of whole or 2% milk may create a richer flavor.

steps.headline: Prepare fluffy angel biscuits.
steps.description: Angel biscuits have a light, airy texture that is accomplished by using both yeast and baking powder to leaven the dough.

steps.headline: Mix in a little cake flour.
steps.description: Cake flour is less dense than all-purpose flour. By swapping some of the all-purpose flour out for a little cake flour, you can create even fluffier biscuits.

steps.headline: Take a shortcut by using prepared baking mix.
steps.description: Commercial baking mix contains a variety of basic ingredients needed for many different baked recipes, including biscuits. You can use it to prepare biscuits by combining the mix with milk, butter, and baking soda. Mimic restaurant-quality cheddar biscuits. By adding cheddar cheese to a biscuit recipe prepared with baking mix, you can easily create cheesy biscuits at home.

steps.headline: Try making vegan biscuits.
steps.description: If you or a dinner guest are on a strict vegan diet, you can make a vegan biscuit alternative by using vegetable shortening and soy milk.

steps.headline: Prepare tea biscuits.
steps.description: If you are more interested in learning how to make crispy biscuits suitable for afternoon tea than fluffy biscuits to serve alongside dinner or breakfast, consider one of the following varieties. Try Viennese biscuits. These biscuits contain the flavors of vanilla, confectioner's sugar, dark chocolate, and butter. Make German biscuits. These crisp, buttery biscuits combine the flavors of spice and citrus. Consider making caramel biscuits. This is a good option for someone with a sweet tooth. These biscuits are infused with the flavors of caramel and coconut. Make butterscotch biscuits. The rich, decadent flavor of butterscotch is baked into these biscuits along with a praline mixture consisting of cashews, almonds, and walnuts. Prepare a batch of almond biscuits. These simple, dainty biscuits have chopped almonds blended in. Create something elegant and aromatic by making rosewater biscuits. These biscuits are prepared with rosewater, giving them a unique flavor. Satisfy your sense of taste and sense of smell with orange blossom biscuits. Orange blossom biscuits are prepared with orange flower water and orange zest.

Yeast Biscuits[1]
	X
		Research source Dissolve the yeast in water. Combine the warm water and yeast in a large bowl, stirring gently only to dissolve the yeast. The water should be between 110 and 115 degrees Fahrenheit (43 and 46 degrees Celsius) in order to activate the yeast properly. Use a food thermometer to check the temperature of the water before you add the yeast. Add the sugar, butter, milk, egg, salt, and whole wheat flour. Combine these ingredients with the yeast-water mixture and beat with a mixing spoon until smooth. You could use an electric mixer set to low speed instead of a mixing spoon, if desired. Make sure to beat the egg slightly with a fork to combine the yolk and white before adding it to the mixture. Use softened butter. To soften butter, let it sit out at room temperature for 30 to 60 minutes. You could also soften butter by microwaving it for 15 seconds at 30 percent power. Add the all-purpose flour. Gradually add the all-purpose flour to the mix, stopping once a soft dough forms. If you have a stand mixer with a dough attachment, you can use it to fold the flour into the dough. If not, you will need to use a mixing spoon or your hands. Do not use an electric hand mixer. Knead the dough. Turn the dough out onto a clean, lightly floured surface and knead until it becomes smooth an elastic. This usually takes about 10 minutes. If the dough sticks to your hands as you knead it, you can apply a light dusting of flour to your hands to help prevent further sticking. Let rise in a warm place. Place the dough in a greased bowl and let it rise, covered, until it doubles in volume. The dough will usually need to rise for about 1 hour and 30 minutes. You can grease the bowl with nonstick cooking spray, butter, or shortening. Turn the dough after putting it into the greased bowl once in order to grease the top. Make sure that the dough is placed in a warm area. Otherwise, it may not reach its full rising potential. Cover the bowl with a lid or warm, moist towel. Punch down the dough and divide it into thirds. After the dough rises, punch it down and separate it into three equal pieces. Allow those three pieces to rest for 5 minutes, regaining some volume in the process. This might be a good time to preheat your oven. Preheat the oven to 375 degrees Fahrenheit (190 degrees Celsius), and prepare a baking sheet by spraying it with nonstick cooking spray or greasing it with butter or shortening. Flatten the dough. Use a rolling pin to flatten each third on a floured counter top. Each piece of dough should be about 1/2 inch (1.25 cm) thick. Rub a little flour onto the rolling pin to prevent it from sticking to the dough. Cut out biscuits. Use a 2.5-inch (6.35-cm) round biscuit cutter to cut out as many biscuits as possible. Transfer these round pieces of dough to your prepared baking sheet and let rise for another 30 minutes, or until doubled in volume. If you do not have a biscuit cutter, you could also use a cookie cutter or the open rim of a glass. Choose a glass with a fairly sharp, well-defined rim in order to create even circles. Cook the biscuits for 10 to 12 minutes. Place the biscuits in your oven, preheated to 375 degrees Fahrenheit (190 degrees Celsius). Back the biscuits until they become golden brown. Serve warm. Remove the pans from the oven and let them cool for several minutes on wire racks. Serve the biscuits once they are cool enough to touch. Always use oven mitts or a thick kitchen towel when handling a hot baking sheet. Baking Powder Biscuits[3]
	X
		Research source Preheat the oven to 425 degrees Fahrenheit (218 degrees Celsius). Prepare a shallow baking sheet by lining it with parchment paper. Alternatively, you could lightly grease the pan with butter, shortening, or nonstick baking spray instead of using parchment paper. If you have a nonstick baking mat, you could use that instead of a prepared baking sheet. Combine the flour, baking powder, and salt. Stir the three ingredients together in a medium to large mixing bowl until thoroughly combined. If desired, you could replace half of the all-purpose flour with whole wheat flour. Cut and put in the butter. Slice the butter into 1/2-inch (1.25-cm) cubes before tossing them into the flour mixture. Blend them into the flour using a pastry blender until large, coarse crumbs form. The crumbs should be about the size of a pea. If you do not have a pastry blender, you could cut the butter into the flour mixture by using two knives to stir and chop the butter while immersed in the flour mixture. Add the milk. Pour the milk in, stirring it into the dry ingredients until moistened. Use a fork or spatula to stir. Stop as soon as the dry ingredients are moistened. Over-mixing the dough could create tough, chewy biscuits. Knead the dough. Turn the dough onto a clean, lightly floured surface and knead several times until the dough sticks together. Gently pat the dough into a rounded or rectangular shape. At this point, the dough should be about 3/4 inch (2 cm) thick. Fold the dough into three sections in order to create biscuits that have multiple, flaky layers. Overlap the ends over the center of the dough, creating a brochure-style fold. After folding the dough, flatten as usual to the specified thickness. Cut out biscuits. Use a round, 3-inch (7.5-cm) biscuit cutter with sharp edges to cut out rounds of dough. Place the biscuits onto your prepared baking sheet, spacing them about 1 inch (2.5 cm) apart. A cookie cutter or the mouth of a glass could be used in the absence of an actual biscuit cutter. After your first batch of biscuits has been cut out, pat the scraps together again so that you can cut out more biscuits from the remaining dough. Continue until all the dough has been used. While circular biscuits are the most traditional shape, you could cut your biscuits into any shape desired. Cutting the biscuits into squares will prevent you from having to roll out any excess dough. Alternatively, create drop biscuits by dropping rounded tablespoons of dough onto your baking sheet. This will create biscuits that are more rustic in appearance. Bake the biscuits for 15 to 18 minutes. The biscuits should be a light, golden brown when done. Note that if you opted to form drop biscuits instead of cut biscuits, the peaks of dough will be slightly darker and crispy when the biscuits are done. Serve warm. The biscuits can be served immediately, or you can let them cool slightly on a wire rack for a few minutes first. Use oven mitts or a thick dish towel when removing the biscuits from the oven. Additional Biscuit Recipes Make biscuits using self-rising flour. Biscuits prepared with self-rising flour may rise better than those made with standard all-purpose flour. Substitute sour cream for the milk. Sour cream biscuits are generally a bit denser, richer, and flatter than those prepared with milk. Use buttermilk. Tangy buttermilk is a common ingredient found in Southern-style biscuits, and using buttermilk instead of whole or 2% milk may create a richer flavor. Prepare fluffy angel biscuits. Angel biscuits have a light, airy texture that is accomplished by using both yeast and baking powder to leaven the dough. Mix in a little cake flour. Cake flour is less dense than all-purpose flour. By swapping some of the all-purpose flour out for a little cake flour, you can create even fluffier biscuits. Take a shortcut by using prepared baking mix. Commercial baking mix contains a variety of basic ingredients needed for many different baked recipes, including biscuits. You can use it to prepare biscuits by combining the mix with milk, butter, and baking soda. Mimic restaurant-quality cheddar biscuits. By adding cheddar cheese to a biscuit recipe prepared with baking mix, you can easily create cheesy biscuits at home. Try making vegan biscuits. If you or a dinner guest are on a strict vegan diet, you can make a vegan biscuit alternative by using vegetable shortening and soy milk. Prepare tea biscuits. If you are more interested in learning how to make crispy biscuits suitable for afternoon tea than fluffy biscuits to serve alongside dinner or breakfast, consider one of the following varieties. Try Viennese biscuits. These biscuits contain the flavors of vanilla, confectioner's sugar, dark chocolate, and butter. Make German biscuits. These crisp, buttery biscuits combine the flavors of spice and citrus. Consider making caramel biscuits. This is a good option for someone with a sweet tooth. These biscuits are infused with the flavors of caramel and coconut. Make butterscotch biscuits. The rich, decadent flavor of butterscotch is baked into these biscuits along with a praline mixture consisting of cashews, almonds, and walnuts. Prepare a batch of almond biscuits. These simple, dainty biscuits have chopped almonds blended in. Create something elegant and aromatic by making rosewater biscuits. These biscuits are prepared with rosewater, giving them a unique flavor. Satisfy your sense of taste and sense of smell with orange blossom biscuits. Orange blossom biscuits are prepared with orange flower water and orange zest.
sentences:
Yeast Biscuits[1]
	X
		Research source Dissolve the yeast in water.
Combine the warm water and yeast in a large bowl, stirring gently only to dissolve the yeast.
The water should be between 110 and 115 degrees Fahrenheit (43 and 46 degrees Celsius) in order to activate the yeast properly.
Use a food thermometer to check the temperature of the water before you add the yeast.
Add the sugar, butter, milk, egg, salt, and whole wheat flour.
Combine these ingredients with the yeast-water mixture and beat with a mixing spoon until smooth.
You could use an electric mixer set to low speed instead of a mixing spoon, if desired.
Make sure to beat the egg slightly with a fork to combine the yolk and white before adding it to the mixture.
Use softened butter.
To soften butter, let it sit out at room temperature for 30 to 60 minutes.
You could also soften butter by microwaving it for 15 seconds at 30 percent power.
Add the all-purpose flour.
Gradually add the all-purpose flour to the mix, stopping once a soft dough forms.
If you have a stand mixer with a dough attachment, you can use it to fold the flour into the dough.
If not, you will need to use a mixing spoon or your hands.
Do not use an electric hand mixer.
Knead the dough.
Turn the dough out onto a clean, lightly floured surface and knead until it becomes smooth an elastic.
This usually takes about 10 minutes.
If the dough sticks to your hands as you knead it, you can apply a light dusting of flour to your hands to help prevent further sticking.
Let rise in a warm place.
Place the dough in a greased bowl and let it rise, covered, until it doubles in volume.
The dough will usually need to rise for about 1 hour and 30 minutes.
You can grease the bowl with nonstick cooking spray, butter, or shortening.
Turn the dough after putting it into the greased bowl once in order to grease the top.
Make sure that the dough is placed in a warm area.
Otherwise, it may not reach its full rising potential.
Cover the bowl with a lid or warm, moist towel.
Punch down the dough and divide it into thirds.
After the dough rises, punch it down and separate it into three equal pieces.
Allow those three pieces to rest for 5 minutes, regaining some volume in the process.
This might be a good time to preheat your oven.
Preheat the oven to 375 degrees Fahrenheit (190 degrees Celsius), and prepare a baking sheet by spraying it with nonstick cooking spray or greasing it with butter or shortening.
Flatten the dough.
Use a rolling pin to flatten each third on a floured counter top.
Each piece of dough should be about 1/2 inch (1.25 cm) thick.
Rub a little flour onto the rolling pin to prevent it from sticking to the dough.
Cut out biscuits.
Use a 2.5-inch (6.35-cm) round biscuit cutter to cut out as many biscuits as possible.
Transfer these round pieces of dough to your prepared baking sheet and let rise for another 30 minutes, or until doubled in volume.
If you do not have a biscuit cutter, you could also use a cookie cutter or the open rim of a glass.
Choose a glass with a fairly sharp, well-defined rim in order to create even circles.
Cook the biscuits for 10 to 12 minutes.
Place the biscuits in your oven, preheated to 375 degrees Fahrenheit (190 degrees Celsius).
Back the biscuits until they become golden brown.
Serve warm.
Remove the pans from the oven and let them cool for several minutes on wire racks.
Serve the biscuits once they are cool enough to touch.
Always use oven mitts or a thick kitchen towel when handling a hot baking sheet.

Baking Powder Biscuits[3]
	X
		Research source Preheat the oven to 425 degrees Fahrenheit (218 degrees Celsius).
Prepare a shallow baking sheet by lining it with parchment paper.
Alternatively, you could lightly grease the pan with butter, shortening, or nonstick baking spray instead of using parchment paper.
If you have a nonstick baking mat, you could use that instead of a prepared baking sheet.
Combine the flour, baking powder, and salt.
Stir the three ingredients together in a medium to large mixing bowl until thoroughly combined.
If desired, you could replace half of the all-purpose flour with whole wheat flour.
Cut and put in the butter.
Slice the butter into 1/2-inch (1.25-cm) cubes before tossing them into the flour mixture.
Blend them into the flour using a pastry blender until large, coarse crumbs form.
The crumbs should be about the size of a pea.
If you do not have a pastry blender, you could cut the butter into the flour mixture by using two knives to stir and chop the butter while immersed in the flour mixture.
Add the milk.
Pour the milk in, stirring it into the dry ingredients until moistened.
Use a fork or spatula to stir.
Stop as soon as the dry ingredients are moistened.
Over-mixing the dough could create tough, chewy biscuits.
Knead the dough.
Turn the dough onto a clean, lightly floured surface and knead several times until the dough sticks together.
Gently pat the dough into a rounded or rectangular shape.
At this point, the dough should be about 3/4 inch (2 cm) thick.
Fold the dough into three sections in order to create biscuits that have multiple, flaky layers.
Overlap the ends over the center of the dough, creating a brochure-style fold.
After folding the dough, flatten as usual to the specified thickness.
Cut out biscuits.
Use a round, 3-inch (7.5-cm) biscuit cutter with sharp edges to cut out rounds of dough.
Place the biscuits onto your prepared baking sheet, spacing them about 1 inch (2.5 cm) apart.
A cookie cutter or the mouth of a glass could be used in the absence of an actual biscuit cutter.
After your first batch of biscuits has been cut out, pat the scraps together again so that you can cut out more biscuits from the remaining dough.
Continue until all the dough has been used.
While circular biscuits are the most traditional shape, you could cut your biscuits into any shape desired.
Cutting the biscuits into squares will prevent you from having to roll out any excess dough.
Alternatively, create drop biscuits by dropping rounded tablespoons of dough onto your baking sheet.
This will create biscuits that are more rustic in appearance.
Bake the biscuits for 15 to 18 minutes.
The biscuits should be a light, golden brown when done.
Note that if you opted to form drop biscuits instead of cut biscuits, the peaks of dough will be slightly darker and crispy when the biscuits are done.
Serve warm.
The biscuits can be served immediately, or you can let them cool slightly on a wire rack for a few minutes first.
Use oven mitts or a thick dish towel when removing the biscuits from the oven.
Additional Biscuit Recipes Make biscuits using self-rising flour.
Biscuits prepared with self-rising flour may rise better than those made with standard all-purpose flour.
Substitute sour cream for the milk.
Sour cream biscuits are generally a bit denser, richer, and flatter than those prepared with milk.
Use buttermilk.
Tangy buttermilk is a common ingredient found in Southern-style biscuits, and using buttermilk instead of whole or 2% milk may create a richer flavor.
Prepare fluffy angel biscuits.
Angel biscuits have a light, airy texture that is accomplished by using both yeast and baking powder to leaven the dough.
Mix in a little cake flour.
Cake flour is less dense than all-purpose flour.
By swapping some of the all-purpose flour out for a little cake flour, you can create even fluffier biscuits.
Take a shortcut by using prepared baking mix.
Commercial baking mix contains a variety of basic ingredients needed for many different baked recipes, including biscuits.
You can use it to prepare biscuits by combining the mix with milk, butter, and baking soda.
Mimic restaurant-quality cheddar biscuits.
By adding cheddar cheese to a biscuit recipe prepared with baking mix, you can easily create cheesy biscuits at home.
Try making vegan biscuits.
If you or a dinner guest are on a strict vegan diet, you can make a vegan biscuit alternative by using vegetable shortening and soy milk.
Prepare tea biscuits.
If you are more interested in learning how to make crispy biscuits suitable for afternoon tea than fluffy biscuits to serve alongside dinner or breakfast, consider one of the following varieties.
Try Viennese biscuits.
These biscuits contain the flavors of vanilla, confectioner's sugar, dark chocolate, and butter.
Make German biscuits.
These crisp, buttery biscuits combine the flavors of spice and citrus.
Consider making caramel biscuits.
This is a good option for someone with a sweet tooth.
These biscuits are infused with the flavors of caramel and coconut.
Make butterscotch biscuits.
The rich, decadent flavor of butterscotch is baked into these biscuits along with a praline mixture consisting of cashews, almonds, and walnuts.
Prepare a batch of almond biscuits.
These simple, dainty biscuits have chopped almonds blended in.
Create something elegant and aromatic by making rosewater biscuits.
These biscuits are prepared with rosewater, giving them a unique flavor.
Satisfy your sense of taste and sense of smell with orange blossom biscuits.
Orange blossom biscuits are prepared with orange flower water and orange zest.
